intro: Braya richardsonii, commonly known as the Richardson's bladderpod, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbage plants, and is characterized by its small, showy flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in alpine or arid environments. It has a basal rosette of leaves and produces pods that contain several seeds. The species is adapted to harsh conditions and is an important part of its native ecosystem.
